newsitem.title: UK: Iran features in wave of fresh sugar freight order.
newsitem.headline: Iran features in wave of fresh sugar freight order.

text.p: London's sugar freight market saw a raft of fresh inquiry at the start of the week but little was reported in the way of firmer business, shipbrokers said on Monday.
Middle East nations such as Iran were prominent among the quoted end-destinations as a result of the recent buying spree seen from Iran's Government trading Corporation (GTC).
Seven Seas was open on account for 3,500/4,000 tonnes of bagged sugar from Port Sudan to Red Sea/Gulf of Aden range for prompt/onwards shipment dates.
Louis Dreyfus quoted for 21,500 tonnes in bulk from Philippines to US west coast for 5/10 March or later.
As expected after Syria's buying tender last week, Lorico came into the freight market for 13,000 tonnes of bulk sugar min/max from Cuba to Syria for 15/25 March.
E D & F Man issued a number of bagged orders with some of last week's still open.
It quoted for 12,000 tonnes from Immingham and Eemshaven to Iran for 17/21 March and a further 12,000 tonnes min/max from Thailand to Pakistan with option of Colombo for 18/25 March.
Man was also open for 6,000 tonnes min/max from Puerto Quetzal with option of east coast Mexico to Angola for prompt shipment dates.

Secretan launched various smaller bagged orders, mostly from European origins. It quoted for 1,500 tonnes from Antwerp to Tallinn for 15/19 March and 6/12,000 tonnes from Calais to Algeria for 24/29 March.
Secretan was also open for 2/3,000 tonnes from Thailand to east Africa for 15/30 March.
Lastly, Ceba Shipping issued an account order on an unnamed account for 14,000 tonnes min/max bagged sugar to be shipped from Bordeaux/Hamburg range to Iran for any March dates with 10 days notice.
In other news, Bangladesh was said to have bought one cargo of white sugar from a leading London trade house.
Sugar traders said the cargo was most likely to be Indian in origin.
Brazil's port of Paranagua was operating normally despite union claims that portworkers were working on a reduced basis and that loadings were already affected.
Port officials earlier said the port was operating normally and denied a union official's claim that the port was running at only 50 percent of normal capacity.
The Paranagua Unions Council said workers planned to strike from 1000 GMT on March 5 over demands for a 21 percent increase in wages which they say they did not receive last year.
Other Brazilian ports would then join the strike on March 6 out of sympathy.
